You were doing good. I mean, going back to just family businesses, all the stuff going on,
you're living in Anaheim Hills, which is a nice spot. I used to do with the city.
And then economy hit. Economy and the IRS.
And the IRS back then, before George Bush Sr., they had carte blanche. They did what they wanted.
And they would accuse you of something and too bad. You had to abide by it. Well,
I didn't owe them any money. And so I fought. And it was an eight-year battle. But that battle
really wiped me out. And I won. I got a little piece of paper that says, George Montserr versus the
IRS, pay nothing. It might have been better off just to write them a check. But I was young. I
was 30 or something, 31. And so I just, you know, that's wrong. And I'm going to fight for it. And
maybe I shouldn't negotiate it. But that kind of money, 800, 600 plus pennies, like 800,000 dollars.
Back in the 70s, you're talking about buying seven or eight million dollar houses in today's market.
Yeah. So anyway, I fought. And then it really crushed us business-wise. And it was amazing,
really, how strong our family was. Because we went from a pretty nice life to me coming home one
day after the banks called me and said, I have been gutted. And I had $29 in my pocket.
And it was kind of struck me as like, I thought I'd feel bad about it. But it was just the money was
gone. I still had my family. And you just work around it. And I took my income definitely changed.
Got a job work as a security guard. And I took the job because they paid every Friday. And I
so I just did that until I put some deals together. And it took a while. And you moved from
Anaheim Hills down to this when you moved down the garden row. Yeah. And this area wasn't the best.
But it was a good experience for my kids. And because they would see when they come to the factory
with me, the factory was down in LA. And that was pretty rough area. And they would see looking out
the window. It's some of these people had it really tough. And we used to have a bear of a man
that would sleep in front of the door on the porch every night. And he wouldn't say anything to me.
It was more of a grunt all the time. And you probably had some mental problems. It was just a huge
guy. And I asked him, I said, are you sleeping here every night? And it was just a kind of a grunt.
Was this of your house? No, this was at the factory in down in LA. And so I thought to myself,
a guy that big, I got no problem with them sleeping here at night because it was a rough area.
So I put blankets out for him. And he stayed there for years. Every morning, I would come in,
bring a big breakfast burrito. He still hardly say anything to grunts. And he would roll up his
blankets and disappear all day. And then an evening he'd come back. And the kids were fasting with
the sky. I wanted to be his friend, but he wasn't buying it. But anyway, they kind of saw that world.
Now we're in an area where it's just a little bit of everything. It was sprinkling of all kinds
of nationalities. And it was a lower income area. And the kids were like,
and from a nice high school with all their friends wealthy, they all go to Europe and all that stuff.
Which I didn't really like them around those kids all the time because I didn't want them to
think this is the way it is. I wanted to see the other side. So it was a good experience. And you've
met my kids. You know they're good with whoever. They just roll with whatever. And the whole
family's that way. So it was good for them. Sarah wasn't thrilled with it. Sorry Sarah. But she ended
up being a leader on the basketball team and all of the kids did great in sports. And all in
all I think it was one of the best things that happened.
